This English version of Lamentations has been prepared by drawing on the following translations: The Stone Edition Tanach, JPS, H.L. Ginsberg, David Seidenberg, James Moffatt, Jerusalem Bible, New King James Bible.

The goal was to create an English reading that can be sung to the traditional trÅps that are used for the Hebrew, but which follows the Hebrew with its trÅps as closely as possible.

If one examines the authoritative translations, it becomes clear that there are many passages in the text of whose meaning the experts are unsure. In those situations I attempted to choose a reading which scans well with the melody, and which agrees with some (or at least one) of the authoritative renderings.

The trÅp melodies I used were taken from the book CHANTING THE HEBREW BIBLE by Joshua R. Jacobson. In order to adapt the trÅp symbols to a left-to-right language like English, I reversed the direction of the following trÅp symbols: mercha tipâ€™cha munach tevir kadma/pashta geresh gershayim

However, I left these the way they are: telisha katana telisha gedola

I also indicate a mercha/tipcha pair or a kadma/geresh pair by â€œwrapping it aroundâ€ the phrase which will have the combined melody, as in: Renew our days She weeps bitterly

I also frequently indicate an entire English phrase to be chanted to a single trÅp melody, as in: clings to her skirts

Chapter 3 of Lamentations is sung by singing each set of three verses to three melodies, in turn.
